title: Hug a polar bear? The bizarre craze that swept interwar Germany
text:
The interwar years in Germany were magical for a photographer – a time of airships, cabaret, automobile races and gorgeously daring fashion. For a small number of outliers, though, it was all about people posing with polar bears. Fake, rather than real, I hasten to add.

Ursus maritimus was having a moment, you see. Probably because a flurry of cubs had joined the inmates at zoos in Hamburg (1910), then Berlin (the Twenties), then Munich (1933). In 1922, Coca-Cola released its first advertisement featuring this wild, white-haired creature. A run on polar bear costumes ensued.

Here’s one with its shaggy great arms around two sweet girls in sailor dresses and polished shoes. Another rides pillion...
